As a lab scientist, what would you do if you need to analyse the data you have collected but you have never done it before? The DS helper team, which is a student-led activity organised within the MRes in Biomedical Research, is here to help you. The project is characterised by different forms of peer-to-peer learning, whose aim is to create an open, friendly, instructive environment where students can reach out in case of issues with data science related topics and can learn some data science if interested.

5 groups of 4 students were tasked with identifying differentially methylateed regions (DMRs) between groups of samples and interpreting the sequence context of these regions. Reducing the dimensionality of the methylation whilst enriching for functionally relevant regions is vital, especially when working with constrained computational resources.

2022-ongoing
LOGML (London Geometry and Machine Learning) aims to bring together mathematicians and computer scientists to work together on a variety of problems at the intersection of geometry and machine learning. There will be a selection of group projects, each overseen by an experienced mentor, talks by leading figures in the field, a variety of social events and a company networking night.






BRAINN Summer School Neuroscience Workshop

2024-08
Hosted by the University of Cyprus on 8-12 July 2024, the BRAINN Summer School offers a unique opportunity for both students and researchers from Cyprus and around the globe to delve into the fascinating world of neuroimaging, neurocognitive assessment, neurocognitive treatment, and non-invasive brain stimulation. Workshop on online neuropsychological assessment methods: remote assessment of cognitive performance and mental health using the Cognitron platform. Hands-on training in collecting and analysing data from online assessment.

QuantumBlack invited me as speakers for a Data Engineering meetup event. I gave a talk on how to use multimodal data to establish the best predictors of Alzheimerâ€™s progression, and discussed more broadly the potential and limitations of AI, and of its applicability in clinical practice.






Imperial College Data Science Society

2021-11
Artificial Intelligence (AI) provides powerful tools that can be applied in many different fields and that are capable of solving complex problems, even beyond what we could have imagined many years ago. In biomedical research, AI algorithms can be used to reach diagnosis, predict disease progression and patientsâ€™ survival, recommend patientsâ€™ treatments and much more, which is all fascinating. But the question is: will these algorithms be ever applied in clinical practice and, in turn, improve people lives?

title: Mingfeng Wang
text:
I am a PhD student affiliated with Institute of Applied Mechanics (MIB) University of Stuttgart and my supervisor is Prof.Â Holger Steeb.
My research focus on numerical simulations of fluid flow in porous media, including single-phase flow, multiphase flow, and reactive flow. These studies have important applications in CO2 geological sequestration, underground wastwater treatment, and oil & gas extraction.
I primarily use OpenFOAM for fluid flow simulations and am capable of developing custom solvers or modules as needed. In addition, I conduct fluid-structure interaction (FSI) simulations using the toolchain OpenFOAM + preCICE + Calculix.
My research interests also include applying machine learning to extract insights from fluid flow data. For example, I have developed machine learning-based methods to derive explicit predictive formulas for the permeability of porous media.

Key topics

Porous Media
Computational Fluid Mechanics (CFD)
Continuum Mechanics
Fluid Structure Interaction (FSI)



Education

PhD student (2021.11 - Present) - University of Stuttgart
Master of Science (2017.09 - 2020.07) - Geological Engineering - China University of Geosciences (Beijing)

Supporting Tools: Yade, Gmsh, Salome, Aviza, ImageJ
